Description: Rim sherd of Chian, possibly Grand Style, pottery heavy chalice; cream slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; part of large and elaborate lotus flower in added red and white; exterior: slip almost completely worn off and only trace of black remaining at bottom of sherd.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The lack of decoration on the exterior surface of the sherd makes it difficult to determine to which style group the sherd belongs. However, the interior decoration is typical of the Grand style and is not observed earlier than c. 580 BC. For parallels regarding the interior decoration see Philadelphia E175A and Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.74.1894.
Also illustrated in Bourriau, J.D., Umm El-Ga`ab (1981) p. 83-84, no. 162a.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 33, no. 12, pl. XVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1644) (phase 2)
